Patricia Patton, PhD

Aligning Human Capital Strategy with Business Strategy Makes Good Sense

"Innovation has nothing to do with how many R&D dollars you have. When Apple came up with the MAC, IBM was spending at least 100 times more on R&D. It’s not about money. It’s about the people you have, how you’ve led and how much you get it” --Steve Jobs

Volatility, uncertainty, turbulence, unprecedented and unstoppable lasting change in a competitive business landscape for some companies means Insurmountable Problems while for others, Unlimited Opportunities.

TO DRIVE GROWTH AND TURN ECONOMIC CHALLENGES INTO THE GREATEST INNOVATIVE BREAKTHROUGHS REQUIRES

Leaders’ Commitment to closely link human capital strategy with the business agenda to make sure that every aspect of the talent strategy directly contributes creating value toward the company mission.

Organization Agility to anticipate, sense, respond and adapt to changes, opportunities and emerging trends and threats with ongoing speed, excellence, execution precision and efficiency

Anticipating the Workforce and Workplace through superior workforce planning that is proactive and able to react to unforeseen changes that will enable workers to shift strategically and effectively. Strong Human Capital analytics that consistently assesses ROI, program impact relative to business goals. Designing environments that manage the realities of how people need to communicate, work together, make decisions and interact on a daily basis.

Building the Pipeline of Skilled Workers to maintain a robust and reliable talent pool and talent lifecycle processes so that each worker is positioned for success from the moment they are hired until they exit the organization. Navigating to a new reality and adapting to change requires strong leadership. Leaders throughout the organization are the engine that steers the business towards its vision.

Capitalizing on Employee Engagement by building cultures and values that create a sense of community where a mosaic of diverse talented employees contribute, belong, make a difference to the world, learn, grow with purpose and have autonomy to create and add value to something greater than themselves and have autonomy to own their destiny.

  • While senior leaders recognize the importance of human capital, only 17% said their workforce strategy is consistently aligned with their business strategy across the organization, while 7% report they consistently utilize quantitative framework in which investments in talent management are aligned with business results.
  • Agile organizations grow revenue 37% faster and generate 30% higher profits than nonagile organizations. Source: MIT Sloan School of Management Study
  • Nearly 90% of executives said they view organizational agility as critical to their business success. Yet a quarter admitted their organizations weren’t agile enough to anticipate the fundamental market shifts. Source: Economist Intelligence Unit Poll report
  • Talent shortage – Employers in advanced economies will likely demand 16 to 18 million more workers with tertiary education by 2020 than their labor markets are likely to have. The 2029 U.S. job market will have 1.5 million fewer college graduates than needed. Source: McKinsey Global Institute, The World at Work Report
  • 31% of employees worldwide is engaged; nearly 17% actively disengaged. Source: BlessingWhite Employee Engagement Report
  • 47,000 employees surveyed globally found only 11% were engaged; 62% were not engaged; 27% were actively disengaged. Source: Gallup Consulting Study
  • 92% of survey respondents report mounting pressure from business leaders and the C-Suite to address engagement related issues. Source: The Conference Board
